headline.main: Important News from the National Capital.; Prompt Measures of the Government to Insure Safety. Additional Orders Regarding the New Levies. IMPORTANT NEWS FROM MISSOURI. Prompt Action Required to Suppress Rebel Movements. Gen. Price's Army Occupying the Principal Towns. Two Brisk Skirmishes NearCharleston.GEN. SIEGEL IN ST. LOUIS. Proceedings of the Western Virginia Convention.Passengers of the Ordinance Establishing a New State.REBEL MOVEMENTS IN NEW-MEXICO.SPECIAL DISPATCH FROM WASHINGTON. STAID UP ALL NIGHT. MORE REBEL PRISONERS. GOING TO EUROPE. GONE TO PENNSYLVANIA. FOR THE LOWER POTOMAC. A GOVERNMENT STORE-HOUSE. GREAT NUMBERS OF TROOPS. FALSE REPORT. COL. MILES' CASE. RELEASED. GEN. ANDERSON. REFUSED TO TAKE THE OATH. DECLINED. TROOPS FROM INDIANA. COMMITTED SUICIDE. DESERTERS FROM THE REBELS. SECOND REGIMENT FIRE ZOUAVES.

docs.lead_paragraph: The arrest of BUTLER, READ and others, in Philadelphia, is only the first manifestation of a purpose which the Government has long entertained, but which has been delayed with a view of obtaining accumulative evidence. For some time past the Government has been satisfied that the rebels were receiving aid, comfort and advice from prominent men at the North, who all the while professed to be warmly in sympathy with the United States.

headline.main: HOW A UNION MAN WAS TREATED IN VIRGINIA.

byline.original: From the St. Louis Denocrat, Aug. 15

docs.snippet: By this time, about every person in the city is aware that martial law has been declared and established therein by Maj-Gen. FREMONT, commanding the Military Department of the West. The legal status also embraces the entire county of St. Louis.

headline.main: MOVEMENTS IN MISSOURI.; ACTIVE MEASURES OF THE PROVOST MARSHAL OF ST. LOUIS.

headline.main: THE SABBATH.; Plea for the Sabbath in War Appeal of the Sabbath Committee.

docs.lead_paragraph: Christian patriots are solicitous that the existing war may be so conducted as to secure the right of our citizen soldiers to their wonted day of rest and worship, and so as to avoid all needless invasion of public morals. A jealous care for the permanent moral foundations of our free institutions should assuredly characterize the struggle for their perpetuation.
